Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: SI2-SSE - A Plug-and-Play Software Platform of Robotics-Inspired Algorithms for Modeling Biomolecular Structures and Motions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a novel plug-and-play platform of open-source software elements to advance algorithmic research in molecular biology. The focus is on addressing the algorithmic impasse faced by computational chemists and biophysicists in structure-function related problems involving dynamic biomolecules central to our biology. The software platform resulting from this project provides the critical software infrastructure to support transformative research in molecular biology and computer science that benefits society at large by advancing our modeling capabilities and in turn our understanding of the role of biomolecules in critical mechanisms in a living and diseased cell.

The project addresses the current impasse on the length and time scales that can be afforded in biomolecular modeling and simulation. It does so by integrating cutting-edge knowledge from two different research communities, computational chemists and biophysicists focused on detailed physics-based simulations, and AI researchers focused on efficient search and optimization algorithms. The software elements integrate sophisticated energetic models and molecular representations with powerful search and optimization algorithms for complex modular systems inspired from robot motion planning. The plug-and-play feature of the software platform supports putting together novel algorithms, such as wrapping Molecular Dynamics or Monte Carlo as local search operators within larger robotics-inspired exploration frameworks, and adding emerging biomolecular representations, models, and search techniques even beyond the timeline of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a plug-and-play open-source software in orderto facilitate collaborative research on biomolecular modeling andsimulation among researchers in AI, robotics, computational chemistry,biology, and biophysics. The software integrates cutting-edgeknowledge from these fields and provide a unified platform that can beused and further enhanced by researchers working on biomolecularmodeling and simulation. The software provides (1) state-of-the-artmolecular representations and energetic models; (2) robotics-inspiredalgorithms for structure and motion computation; and (3) standardizedperformance and data analysis. In so doing, the software promises toaddress the algorithmic impasse in protein and peptide modeling andsimulation, while at the same time advance the applicability ofrobotics-inspired algorithms on structure function related problems.

The software, ROMEO, provides a platform for "Robotics-inspiredAlgorithms for Modeling Biomolecular Structures and Motions" as wellas several molecular structure data analysis and visualizationalgorithms.  ROMEO follows a plug-and-play architecture to facilitatenovel algorithmic design and so allow researchers to further advancealgorithmic research in molecular biology. ROMEO is written in C++ andits object-oriented design allows easy adaptation and expansion.

The software elements resulting from this project have been disseminated via publications, workshops, tutorials, and softwaredemonstrations. The software has been adopted by numerous academicinstitutions worldwide as well as federal labs at National CancerInstitute and Los Alamos Federal Lab.

This project provides a general platform for the development ofalgorithms related to structure and motion.  As such, the project hasthe potential to improve our understanding of molecular mechanisms incells.

The project also had a broader impact on education. High-school, undergraduate, and graduate students were exposed to and immersed inresearch. Teaching modules were developed and used in Robotics and AIcourses.


Last Modified: 06/01/2019
Modified by: Erion Plaku
